standard_metadata.standard_description: Solve real world problems involving division of unit fractions by non-zero whole numbers and division of whole numbers by unit fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Fraction and whole number division in contexts

question.content: Nikita has $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a kilogram of trail mix.  She wants to share it equally among herself and her $2$  cousins.  How much trail mix will each person get?  **Which expression could represent this situation?**

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
There are $\greenD3$ people eating trail mix. Altogether, they will eat a total of $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ kilograms.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two tape diagrams of equal length. The top diagram is labeled one-third. The bottom diagram is divided into 3 equal-sized parts. Each part is labeled question mark. Across the bottom diagram there is a curved bracket labeled 3 equal groups.

hints.content: The expression that will tell us how much each person will eat is $\purpleD{\dfrac13}\div\greenD3$.

question.content: Bobby has $\dfrac{1}{7}$ of a kilogram of gold.  He wants to share it equally between himself and $1$ friend.   How much gold will each person get?  **Which expression could represent this situation?**

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
There are $\greenD2$ people taking gold. Altogether, they will take a total of $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{7}}$ kilograms.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two tape diagrams of equal length. The top diagram is labeled one-seventh. The bottom diagram is divided into 2 equal-sized parts. Each part is labeled question mark. Across the bottom diagram there is a curved bracket labeled 2 equal groups.

hints.content: The expression that will tell us how much gold each person will get is $\purpleD{\dfrac17}\div\greenD2$.

question.content: Watkins Elementary School is painting the desks.  Each desk takes $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a liter of paint.  If the school buys $6$ liters of paint, how many desks can they paint?  **Which expression could represent this situation?**

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Each desk takes $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ liters of paint . Altogether, they will take a total of $\purpleD{6}$ liters.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt:
A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths, a
first tape labeled 6 and a shorter second tape with
one part labeled one-third. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the first tape is labeled
with a question mark and the words equal groups.

hints.content: The expression that will tell us how many desks they can paint is $\purpleD{6}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$.

question.content: A gymnastics class is having blueberries for a snack. A serving size of blueberries is $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a bowl.  If there are $3$ bowls of blueberries, how many gymnasts can get a snack?  **Which expression could represent this situation?**

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Each gymnast takes $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of a bowl of blueberries. Altogether, they will take a total of $\purpleD{3}$ bowls.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths, a first tape labeled 3 and a shorter second tape with one part labeled one-fourth. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the first tape is labeled with a question mark and the words equal groups.

hints.content: The expression that will tell us how many gymnasts will get a snack is $\purpleD{3}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.

question.content: Jenna bought some chocolate for her friends. She wants to give $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of a bar of chocolate to each friend.  Jenna has $7$ bars of chocolate.   How many friends can she give her chocolate to?  **Which expression could represent this situation?**

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Each friend takes $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ of a bar of chocolate. Altogether, they will take a total of $\purpleD{7}$ bars.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths, a first tape labeled 7 and a shorter second tape with one part labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the first tape is labeled with a question mark and the words equal groups.

hints.content: The expression that will tell us how many friends Jenna can give chocolate to is $\purpleD{7}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$.

question.content: William, his brother, and their $3$ sisters won $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of the science fair prize money.  What fraction of the prize money will each sibling receive if the $5$ of them split the prize equally?  **Which expression could represent this situation?**

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
There are $\greenD5$ people taking prize money. Altogether, they will take a total of $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ of the prize money.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two tape diagrams of equal length. The top diagram is labeled one-half.  The bottom diagram is divided into 5 equal-sized parts. Each part is labeled question mark. Across the bottom diagram there is a curved bracket labeled 5 equal groups.

hints.content: The expression that will tell us what fraction of the prize money each person will get is  $\purpleD{\dfrac12}\div\greenD5$.

question.content: Chamberlin wants to bottle $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of her apple cider.  She pours the apple cider evenly among $6$ bottles. What fraction of her apple cider will she put in each bottle$?$  **Which expression could represent this situation?**

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
There are $\greenD6$ bottles to pour apple cider into. Altogether, they will take a total of $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ of all the apple cider.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two tape diagrams of equal length. The top diagram is labeled one-eighth. The bottom diagram is divided into 6 equal-sized parts. Each part is labeled question mark. Across the bottom diagram there is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: The expression that will tell us what fraction of the apple cider each bottle will get is $\purpleD{\dfrac18}\div\greenD6$.

question.content: Brennan is planting seeds.  He has $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of a pack of seeds and $5$ flower pots. He wants to use the same amount of seeds in each pot.  What fraction of a pack of seeds will be planted in each flower pot?  **Which expression could represent this situation?**

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
There are $\greenD5$ flower pots to put seeds in. Altogether, they will take a total of $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ of all the seed pack.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two tape diagrams of equal length. The top diagram is labeled one-fifth. The bottom diagram is divided into 5 equal-sized parts. Each part is labeled question mark. Across the bottom diagram there is a curved bracket labeled 5 equal groups.

hints.content: The expression that will tell us what fraction of the seed pack each flower pot will get is $\purpleD{\dfrac15}\div\greenD5$.

options.content: Jenae has $\dfrac12$ kilogram of trail mix.  She splits her trail mix evenly between $7$ friends.  How much trail mix will each friend get?
Cara ordered $7$ pizzas for her birthday party.  Her parents ate $\dfrac12$ of a pizza before the party.  How much pizza is left for the party?
Walt has $7$ hamsters.  Each hamster weighs $\dfrac12$ kilogram.  What is the total weight of the hamsters?

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

The expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\div\greenD7$ can represent $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ split evenly into $\greenD7$ groups.  In which problem do we split $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ into $\greenD7$ equal groups?
###Cara  We want to find out how much pizza is left for the party, so we subtract $\greenD{7}-\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\div\greenD7$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Walt  We want to find out the total weight of all $\greenD7$ hamsters, so we multiply $\greenD{7} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\div\greenD7$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Janae  We want to split the $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ kg evenly between $\greenD7$ friends.  So, we divide $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\div\greenD7$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\div \greenD7$ helps us solve this problem!

The expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\div \greenD7$ can solve the following context:  - Jenae has $\dfrac12$ kilogram of trail mix.  She splits her trail mix evenly between $7$ friends.  How much trail mix will each friend get?

options.content: Troy is making pizzas. He has $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a kilogram of cheese.  He spreads the cheese equally between $3$ pizzas. How many kilograms of cheese does he put on each pizza?
Mike bought $3$ donuts.  He ate $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a donut. How many donuts are left?
Karla has $3$ bottles. Each bottle has $\dfrac{1}{4}$ liter of soda in it.  How much soda does Karla have in all?

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

The expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\greenD3$ can represent $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ split evenly into $\greenD3$ groups.  In which problem do we split $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ into $\greenD3$ equal groups?
###Mike  We want to find out how many donuts are left, so we subtract $\greenD{3}-\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\greenD3$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Karla  We want to find out the total amount of soda in all $\greenD3$ bottles, so we multiply $\greenD{3} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\greenD3$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Troy  We want to split the $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ kilograms evenly between $\greenD3$ pizzas.  So, we divide $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\greenD3$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div \greenD3$ helps us solve this problem!

The expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div \greenD3$ can solve the following context:  - Troy is making pizzas. He has $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a kilogram of cheese.  He spreads the cheese equally between $3$ pizzas. How many kilograms of cheese does he put on each pizza?

options.content: $4$ friends are running in a relay race. The race is $\dfrac{1}{3}\text{ km}$ long. How many kilometers will each friend run?
The local ice cream shop is opening for the summer. They have $4$ liters of milk. Each liter of milk needs $\dfrac13$ bag of ice cream mix. How many bags of ice cream mix do they need?
Erica has $\dfrac13$ bag of candy. For her birthday, she receives $4$ more bags of candy. How much candy does Erica have in total?

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

The expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\greenD4$ can represent $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ split evenly into $\greenD4$ groups.  In which problem do we split $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ into $\greenD4$ equal groups?

###Erica  We want to find out how many bags of candy we have after getting more, so we add $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}} +\greenD4$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\greenD4$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Ice cream shop  We want to find out the total amount of ice cream mix needed for all $\greenD4$ liters of milk, so we multiply $\greenD{4} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\greenD4$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Relay race  We want to split the $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ kilometer evenly between $\greenD4$ runners.  So, we divide $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\greenD4$.  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div \greenD4$ helps us solve this problem!

The expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\greenD4$ can solve the following context:  - $4$ friends are running in a relay race. The race is $\dfrac{1}{3}\text{ km}$ long. How many kilometers will each friend run?

options.content: Nicole bought a $5\text{ kg}$ bag of flour. Every morning, she uses $\dfrac16\text{ kg}$ of flour  to make pancakes. How many days will the bag last?
Connor has $\dfrac16$ bag of potato chips. He wants to share the chips evenly between $5$ of his friends. How much will each friend receive?
Molly brought $5$ liters of juice to school. Todd brought $\dfrac16$ liter of juice to school. How much juice do they have combined?

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

The expression $\purpleD{5}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ can represent $\purpleD5$ split evenly into groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.   In which problem do we split $\purpleD5$ into groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$?

###Molly and Todd  We want to find out how many liters of juice they have together, so we add $\purpleD5 + \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.  $\purpleD{5}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Connor  We want to split the $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ of the bag evenly between $\purpleD5$ friends.  So, we divide $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}\div\purpleD5$.  $\purpleD{5}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Nicole  We want to split the $\purpleD5$ kg flour between groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ per day.  So, we divide $\purpleD{5}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ .  $\purpleD{5}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ helps us solve this problem!

The expression $\purpleD{5}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ can solve the following context:  - Nicole bought a $5\text{ kg}$ bag of flour. Every morning, she uses $\dfrac16\text{ kg}$ of flour  to make pancakes. How many days will the bag last?

options.content: Kim wants to run a total of $2\text{ km}$ in one week. She runs $\dfrac18\text{ km}$ at a time. How many times will Kim need to run to complete her goal of $2\text{ km}$?
Garret has $2\text{ kg}$ of flour. He mixes the flour with $\dfrac18\text{ kg}$ of sugar. How much flour and sugar does he have combined?
A bread factory puts $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a barrel of flour into each batch of dough. How much flour will the factory use for $2$ batches of dough?

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

The expression $\purpleD{2}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ can represent $\purpleD2$ split evenly into groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$.  In which problem do we split $\purpleD2$ into groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$?

###Garret  We want to find out how many kilograms of flour and sugar we have together, so we add $\purpleD2 + \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$.  $\purpleD{2}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Bread factory  We put $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ of the barrel of flour into each of $\purpleD2$ batches.  So, we multiply $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}\times\purpleD2$.  $\purpleD{2}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Kim  We want to split the $\purpleD2$ kilometers between groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$.  So, we divide $\purpleD{2}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ .  $\purpleD{2}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ helps us solve this problem!

The expression $\purpleD{2}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ can solve the following context:  - Kim wants to run a total of $2\text{ km}$ in one week. She runs $\dfrac18\text{ km}$ at a time. How many times will Kim need to run to complete her goal of $2\text{ km}$?

options.content: A baker is making biscuits. She has $6\text{ kg}$ of dough. Each biscuit is made with $\dfrac15\text{ kg}$ of dough. How many biscuits can she make?
Cooper made enough chocolate ice cream to fill $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of a carton. He made $6$ times as much vanilla ice cream.  How many cartons can he fill with vanilla ice cream?
Emma wants to make $6$ batches of cupcakes. Each batch uses $\dfrac15$ liter of milk. How much milk will Emma use?

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

The expression $\purpleD{6}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ can represent $\purpleD6$ split evenly into groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$.  In which problem do we split $\purpleD6$ into groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$?

###Emma  We want to find the total amount of milk needed for all  $\purpleD6$ batches. So, we multiply $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}\times\purpleD6$.  $\purpleD{6}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Cooper  We want to find the total number of vanilla ice cream cartons filled by $\purpleD6$ times the amount of chocolate ice cream. So, we multiply $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}\times\purpleD6$.  $\purpleD{6}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###Baker  We want to split the $\purpleD6$ kilograms of dough into groups of $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$.  So, we divide $\purpleD{6}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ .  $\purpleD{6}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ helps us solve this problem!

The expression $\purpleD{6}\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ can solve the following context:  - A baker is making biscuits. She has $6\text{ kg}$ of dough. Each biscuit is made with $\dfrac15\text{ kg}$ of dough. How many biscuit can she make?
